end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2010

video_links.name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Main Trailer

end.brief_description: Harry, Ron and Hermione walk away from their last year at Hogwarts to find and destroy the remaining Horcruxes, putting an end to Voldemort’s bid for immortality. But with Voldemort’s Death Eaters on the loose, the world is more dangerous than ever.

constellations_other.name: Reflecting duality and revealing new realities
constellations_other.description: The Toupie Fantoche relies on four prismatic mirrors to reflect changes in animation states.

constellations_other.name: Shadowplay and spookiness

links.description: ‘The Tale of the Three Brothers’ in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 invokes Reiniger’s silhouette animation style. Animation supervisor Dale Newton has cited Reiniger as a direct influence on the animation.

end.title: Bram Stoker's Dracula
end.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Charles Mulvehill, Fred Fuchs, American Zoetrope and Osiris Films
end.brief_description: Francis Ford Coppola’s lavish new version of Bram Stoker’s classic novel is visually stunning, filled with images of both beauty and horror. Dracula is played brilliantly by Gary Oldman, and his archrival Dr. Van Helsing is played by Sir Anthony Hopkins.

constellations_other.description: Edie Kurzer's costume design work on Judy & Punch and Picnic at Hanging Rock is part of a larger trend in Australian films and TV series.

links.description: The all-silhouette 15th century battle scenes in Francis Ford Coppola’s Bram Stoker’s Dracula directly reference Reiniger’s animation style. Later Coppola reinvents Reiniger’s puppets during a scene in an early movie-slash-arcade.

start.title: Nosferatu
start.creator_credit: Albin Grau, Enrico Dieckmann and Jofa-Atelier Berlin-Johannisthal
start.brief_description: Vampire Count Orlok isn’t just interested in a new residence, but also the wife of his young real estate agent in F.W. Murnau’s unauthorised adaptation of Bram Stoker’s Dracula. Shot in the German Expressionist style, this groundbreaking vampire film influenced film noir and Hollywood horrors.

constellations_other.name: Spooky shadows
constellations_other.description: Hellish and hilarious vampires connect pioneering German cinema to contemporary New Zealand comedy with a quick detour into small town strangeness.

constellations_other.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_other.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

end.title: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night
end.brief_description: Dracula’s castle has risen again and it’s up to the mysterious Alucard to face Dracula and save the world. Though not considered successful at release, it’s become the blueprint for successive games in the series.

constellations_other.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_other.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

links.description: While Count Orlock is a substitute for Dracula in Nosferatu, Olrox (get it) in Castlevania: Symphony of Night is inspired by the iconic cinematic vampire. In Japanese media he’s even just plainly called Orlok.

end.title: The Golem
end.creator_credit: Hanns Lippmann, Henrik Galeen and Paul Wegener
end.brief_description: Der Golem (The Golem) is a 1915 German silent horror film, partly lost, that was written and directed by Paul Wegener and Henrik Galeen, and inspired by the ancient Jewish legend.

constellations_other.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_other.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

links.description: Animation pioneer Lotte Reiniger’s The Adventures of Prince Achmed is widely recognised as the first animated feature film and was groundbreaking in its use of silhouette stop-motion animation. Reiniger was inspired by the dreamy horrors of Paul Wegener like The Golem.

links.description: Silhouette, shadow and projection also plays a key role in the first vampire movie – Nosferatu – which is also an unauthorised adaptation of Bram Stoker’s Dracula. In a famous scene, the vampire Count Orlok’s shadow is seen gliding up a set of stairs before he attacks Ellen in her sleep.

results.name: Access to resistance
results.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

key_work.title: National Portable Video Camera WV-3085
key_work.brief_description: The Portapak system is a handheld video camera with separate reel-to-reel video recorder. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism.

constellations_primary.name: Access to resistance
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

start.title: Chauka, Please Tell Us The Time
start.brief_description: An urgent and powerful documentary, secretly filmed on a phone inside the Manus Island detention centre, where asylum seekers trying to reach Australia are indefinitely detained, by Iranian Kurdish journalist Behrouz Boochani, in collaboration with Dutch Iranian filmmaker Arash Kamali Sarvestani.

constellations_primary.name: Seeking asylum
constellations_primary.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

end.title: Escape from Woomera
end.brief_description: Escape from Woomera is a videogame that asks players to experience Australia’s draconian immigration policies from the point-of-view of a refugee. By combining game mechanics, art and activism, Escape from Woomera goes beyond the razor wire and detention centre media blackout.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

links.description: Drawing attention to social and humanitarian issues in Australia crossed into videogames thanks to accessible open source coding, which was used to create Escape from Woomera, a game that exposed the desperate situation and dehumanising effects of detention.

start.title: Punk Prayer - Mother of God, Chase Putin Away!
start.brief_description: In 2012, Pussy Riot staged a performance on the soleas of a Moscow cathedral to protest the Orthodox Church’s support of Putin’s election campaign. Though two members were arrested and jailed, the other members of the group made the performance into a music video.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

constellations_primary.name: Seeking asylum
constellations_primary.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

links.description: Kurdish Iranian refugee Behrouz Boocchani used an iPhone to create a documentary inside the Manus Island detention centre, smuggling the footage to filmmaker Arash Kamli Sarvestani. Like Pussy Riot, access to smaller, portable recording devices helped Boochani challenge political institutions.

start.title: Semiotics of the Kitchen
start.brief_description: Semiotics of the Kitchen is a feminist parody single-channel video and performance piece released in 1975 by Martha Rosler. The video, which runs six minutes, is considered a critique of the commodified versions of traditional women’s roles in modern society.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

end.title: Punk Prayer - Mother of God, Chase Putin Away!
end.brief_description: In 2012, Pussy Riot staged a performance on the soleas of a Moscow cathedral to protest the Orthodox Church’s support of Putin’s election campaign. Though two members were arrested and jailed, the other members of the group made the performance into a music video.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

links.description: 38 years later, Russian activists and musicians Pussy Riot harnessed the ease of access to equipment and video hosting platforms to share a performative demonstration through music video “Punk Prayer - Mother of God, Chase Putin Away!”. It was banned in Russia for criticising ties between church and state.

start.brief_description: The Portapak system is a handheld video camera with separate reel-to-reel video recorder. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism.

constellations_primary.name: Access to resistance
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

end.title: Semiotics of the Kitchen
end.brief_description: Semiotics of the Kitchen is a feminist parody single-channel video and performance piece released in 1975 by Martha Rosler. The video, which runs six minutes, is considered a critique of the commodified versions of traditional women’s roles in modern society.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

links.description: The affordability and accessibility of the Portapak enabled a video art revolution, coinciding with Second Wave feminism. Martha Rosler’s Semiotics of the Kitchen challenges domestic stereotypes through a satirical Julia Childs-like cooking video.

results.name: Page to screen
results.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

key_work.title: My Brilliant Career
key_work.credit_line:
Courtesy Margaret Fink Films

Held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
key_work.brief_description: A key work in the Australian New Wave film movement, My Brilliant Career was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Page to screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_other.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

end.title: Seven Little Australians (1973)
end.brief_description: Captain Wolcott is a widower with seven children. He marries again and his new wife takes on all the trials of bringing up seven spirited children. They have many adventures, especially one daughter Helen, commonly known as Judy.

constellations_other.name: Page to screen

links.description: Before writing the screenplay of the 1979 breakthrough film My Brilliant Career, Eleanor Witcombe had successfully adapted another novel, Ethel Turner’s Seven Little Australians, as a 10 TV part mini-series in 1973.

start.title: The Eye of the Storm
start.brief_description: In a Sydney suburb, two nurses, Maria and Flora, a housekeeper, Lotte, and a solicitor, Arnold, attend to Elizabeth Hunter as her expatriate son Sir Basil, a famous but struggling actor in London, and daughter Dorothy, a divorced and down at heel princess, convene at her deathbed. They come to make sure they can leave Australia with their hefty inheritance.

end.title: Number 96
end.brief_description: Number 96 was a popular soap set in a Sydney apartment block. Cash Harmon Television produced the series for Network Ten, which requested a Coronation Street-type serial, and specifically one that explored adult subjects.

constellations_other.name: 1970s TV
constellations_other.description: The 1970s was a thrilling time in Australian television as productions expanded in scale, scope, and ambition.

constellations_other.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

links.description: Eleanor Witcombe (1923–2018) wrote the script of My Brilliant Career (1979) based on the 1901 novel written by the feminist Miles Franklin (1879–1954). Earlier in the 1970s, Witcombe also scripted two episodes of the sexually frank Australian soap opera Number 96.

start.title: Seven Little Australians
start.brief_description: Seven children live with their tyrannical father, Captain McCallum, and step mother Esther. The children can never make their father happy.

links.description: Almost 40 years after her screen debut, Elizabeth Alexander, now a veteran of film and TV, played a minor character in another major literary page-to-screen adaptation: The Eye of the Storm. The screenplay, adapted from Nobel Prize-winner Patrick White’s novel, was scripted by Judy Morris.

results.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
results.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

key_work.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
key_work.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

start.title: Samson et Dalila
start.brief_description: Ferdinand Zecca’s 1902 adaptation of the biblical story of Samson and Delilah is an early silent film, shot in black-and-white. Later frames were hand-painted to bring vibrancy and depth.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

end.title: The Ten Commandments
end.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille
end.brief_description: Directed by Cecil B. DeMille and written by Jeanie MacPherson, the film is divided into two parts: a prologue recreating the biblical story of the Exodus and a modern story concerning two brothers and their respective views of the Ten Commandments.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

links.description: Cecil B. DeMille also adapted biblical stories for the screen. The Ten Commandments was lauded for its early special effects depicting the parting of the red sea and its use of the Technicolor 2 Process in some scenes.

start.title: Samson and Delilah
start.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
start.brief_description: Cecil B. De Mille’s famous epic style is highlighted in this classic bible story about the legendary strongman Samson and the temptress Delilah, who helped destroy him. Lauded for its lush cinematography, performances, costumes, sets and special effects, it was a box office smash.

constellations_other.name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

end.title: South Park
end.creator_credit: Braniff
end.brief_description: When South Park debuted in 1997, it became the first animated pop culture phenomenon since The Simpsons. Known for pushing boundaries and controversial satire, it follows four boys in a sleepy Colorado town but really traverses current events and pop culture.

constellations_other.name: Evangelical animation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation exploring animation was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Melanie Kavanagh.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

links.description: While religious stories helped studios avoid censorship in early Hollywood, religious beliefs have led to censorship on TV. South Park episode 201 controversially featured a depiction of the Prophet Muhammad and was censored by Comedy Central.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

links.description: Though rationing during WWII meant less biblical epics were made in Hollywood, DeMille returned with the blockbuster Samson and Delilah in 1949. Biblical epics were popular in early Hollywood as they could bypass the Production Code to include violence and sex.

start.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
start.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

end.title: Samson et Dalila
end.brief_description: Ferdinand Zecca’s 1902 adaptation of the biblical story of Samson and Delilah is an early silent film, shot in black-and-white. Later frames were hand-painted to bring vibrancy and depth.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

links.description: The Blind man of Siloam is a magic lantern show created by the Salvation Army in Melbourne. The familiar biblical story was made by printing photos on magic lantern slides and hand-painting them. Similarly, Ferdinand Zecca’s Samson et Dalila featured hand-painted frames.

start.title: South Park
start.brief_description: When South Park debuted in 1997, it became the first animated pop culture phenomenon since The Simpsons. Known for pushing boundaries and controversial satire, it follows four boys in a sleepy Colorado town but really traverses current events and pop culture.

constellations_other.name: Evangelical animation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation exploring animation was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Melanie Kavanagh.

end.title: Resistance: Fall of Man
end.brief_description: In an alternate 1951, Sgt. Nathan Hale is among a unit of US soldiers sent to aid the British military against invading aliens, known as Chimera. When Hale’s unit is completely wiped out in a surprise attack, he struggles for survival.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

links.description: Religious considerations can also affect videogames. The Church of England took offense when the real world Manchester Cathedral appeared in first-person shooter, Resistance: Fall of Man. The church took legal action against Sony for “digital desecration”, who initially pulled the game from shelves.

constellations_other.description: Beginning with an anamorphic image of Napoleon III, this Constellation focuses on representations of the distorted perspective of patriarchal power.

links.description: Anamorphic artworks distort perspectives of history, both literally and metaphorically. France’s Napoleon III (who features in the anamorphic drawing display) and Italy’s Mussolini both suspended political freedoms to seize power. Kentridge’s work concerns Mussolini’s invasion of Ethiopia and highlights the recurring nature of history.

results.name: Dismissing the truth
results.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

key_work.title: Gough Whitlam - Dismissal

start.title: The Dressmaker
start.brief_description: In 1950s Australia, beautiful, talented dressmaker Tilly returns to her tiny hometown to right wrongs from her past. As she tries to reconcile with her mother, she starts to fall in love while transforming the fashion of the town.

constellations_other.name: Atari’s Basketball
constellations_other.description: Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, Atari’s Basketball was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. This set the standard for basketball games that followed.
